{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3528790,"name":"raj","username":"jedimaster07812","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/e99b99/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-16T17:12:46.028Z","cooked":"

Hey guys! I hope all of y’all’s builds are going well as we get closer to competitions! Our team has been experimenting with a few protective measures to prevent coral from getting stuck inside our robot and damaging electronics and mechanisms at the base of our robot. At the back of our robot, we are planning on pulling a 1323 and making a very big box since we have nothing leaving the frame perimeter on that side, but are having more issues with the front on our scoring and elevator side. We’ve tried some setups with fabric and polycarbonate and haven’t had much success. What are ways that teams are preventing coral from falling into their robot, especially beneath an elevator when it is extended? Any help or ideas would be appreciated. Thanks!

Just gonna link in a few threads:

Main coral will ruin seasons thread:

Coral will Ruin Seasons General Forum
For anybody who hasn’t yet had the chance to run some Coral cycles, one quick lesson 6045 has learned is that L4 Coral has a lot of potential energy. Unfortunately when you miss your attempt at scoring the Coral on L4, that potential energy converts to kinetic energy. Coral with kinetic energy doesn’t play well with sensitive electronics in a robot’s belly pan. There’s a lot of things teams can (and should) do to protect their robots against falling Coral. My personal favorite solution is doing…

Sponsor panels as part of bumpers acting as shields:

2025 Team Update 09 General Forum
I don’t think this changes anything about sponsor panels attached to bumpers. The rule update modifies the wording of R411 to apply only to the BUMPER cover (already defined in R402C as the cloth that covers all upward, downward and outward facing surfaces of the padding) and require that up/down/out facing surfaces of the cover must be the alliance color, and modifies R412 to specify that team numbers must be on the cover. Sponsor panels like 2910 used in 2023 are part of the Fastening Syste…

Bottom mount critical components:

WildStang Robotics Program: Team 111 and 112 Build Blog - 2025 FRC Open Alliance
Build Update 1/25/25 [PXL_20250125_220649411] We finished assembling and wiring the drivebase and most of the lift today! We were able to do a test pull of the rigging today. We’ll assemble the torque tube and finish rigging the lift on Monday. [111 Elevator Rigging Test] We were surprised by how high the elevator goes; the bot extends to about 10 feet high with the arm! We have LEDs inside of the tubes, and we think they look super cool. We’re using a REV Blinkin to control the…

… Any of the various swerve covers, particularly for things like exposed encoders / motor controllers / cameras

Something like this plastic split wire loom/conduit is probably decent protection from falling coral. They also make non-split versions which would probably be a little more protective but harder to add on to already run wires.

Suppdog222:

What are some ways teams protect exposed wires that can’t be covered by a lexan panel?

I’m not particularly concerned about bare wire. I’ll zip tie it using cheap mounts and cable ties for strain relief and neatness, but that’s about it. (Wipe the spot down with an alcohol wipe right before and let it dry, it’ll do wonders for adhesion.)

For things that might crack or get bumped like in that 111 video, I’m planning a mix of foam floor tiles or 3D printing guards out of TPU to absorb the whack.

Or, if the lexan poses a cost issue rather than an engineering issue, corrugated plastic (think yard sign material) will get you a lot of the way at a very nice price.

Garrison:

Something like this plastic split wire loom/conduit

Cheaper from Harbor Freight, if one is nearby. You can also use the igus energy chain that’s been in past kits of parts; if you don’t have it around, other teams nearby might. Or use your Automation Direct voucher on some of their energy chain.

you should come to SCRIW in October"},"post_url":"/t/protecting-robot-from-game-pieces/491932/6","custom_user_title":"says you should come to SCRIW in October","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534611,"name":"","username":"Mangos","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mangos/{size}/208435_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T19:35:58.526Z","cooked":"

Hi! Our robot currently has a total of 4 panels: Front electronics panel, two side panels, and one rear panel. The most tested one is the front electronics panel as falling coral from L4 as it is regularly struck. From testing, other panels haven’t been hit yet but we feel it is a necessary precaution. Despite the “overprotection”, the coral has gone into the box of a bot through the bottom of the extended elevator twice. We are seeing if we can make a net from surgical tubing from the chassis to the bottom of the first stage that extends with the elevator.

Mangos:

Despite the “overprotection”, the coral has gone into the box of a bot through the bottom of the extended elevator twice. We are seeing if we can make a net from surgical tubing from the chassis to the bottom of the first stage that extends with the elevator.

Do you have a picture of this? It’s tough to get a sense of what you’re running up against.
